;周一，联合国几个主要机构的负责人一致呼吁在以色列发动袭击时在加沙实现人道主义停火<近一个月以来，冲突加剧;。 /p>;

;18 位签署者包括联合国人权事务高级专员沃尔克·特克 (Volker Turk)、世界卫生组织总干事谭德塞 (Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus) 和联合国援助负责人马丁·格里菲思 (Martin Griffiths)。

;

;“他们在一份联合声明中表示，人们遭到围困和攻击，无法获得生存必需品，他们的家园、避难所、医院和礼拜场所遭到轰炸。这是不可接受的。

;

;“我们需要立即人道主义停火。已经过去 30 天了。受够了。现在必须停止。”

;

;格里菲斯周五呼吁 ;以色列轰炸人口稠密的巴勒斯坦飞地的人道主义行动“暂停”;，以帮助运送援助物资，而援助物资的交付量远远低于预- 冲突程度。

;

;巴勒斯坦驻联合国特使里亚德·曼苏尔回应说，格里菲斯应该呼吁全面停火。

;

;“你应该根据国际人道法（国际人道法）清楚而大声地说人道主义法）认为应该停火，”曼苏尔说。

;

;“应该采取拯救生命的行动。应立即停止所有这些敌对行动。这就是我对你的期望。”

;

;以色列有 ;拒绝;国际社会要求停火的压力越来越大，并表示哈马斯武装分子10月7日在以色列南部肆虐期间劫持的人质应该被释放。

;全球呼吁在;以色列与哈马斯的战争没有受到重视，导致人道主义援助物资短缺，无法进入以色列围困的加沙地带。食品、燃料、饮用水和药品的供应状况恶化。

;

;以下是一些联合国机构所谓的“人道主义”的概要;灾难;”笼罩着哈马斯统治的230万人口的小飞地。

;

;大约150万人——超过人口的一半联合国人道主义事务办公室 (OCHA) 表示，加沙地带的难民已逃离家园，超过 70 万人在联合国巴勒斯坦难民机构 (UNRWA) 管理的建筑物中避难。数以万计的人在医院和教堂里。

;

;近东救济工程处南部的避难所人满为患，无法容纳新来的人，许多流离失所者睡在避难所附近的街道上，人道协调厅表示。近东救济工程处无法再向北部的流离失所者提供援助，自 10 月 27 日以来，这里一直是以色列扩大地面行动的重点。

;

;以色列已向加沙北部（哈马斯的核心地区）的平民发出呼吁。部队 - 为了自身安全而撤离到南部，并在 11 月 5 日给出了具体的时间窗口。

;

;然而，联合国监测显示，只有不到 2,000 人这样做，理由是恐惧、严重破坏世界卫生组织 (WHO) 称，加沙 35 家医院中有超过三分之一无法正常运转，仍在使用的医院报告称，燃料严重短缺，导致电力供应严重减少。 ）说。

;

;人道协调厅表示，两家医院（希法医院和印度尼西亚医院）的发电机由于缺乏燃料而停止工作，每天仅使用备用发电机运行几个小时，仅用于关键服务。

;

;然而，以色列官员对燃料短缺的警告提出异议，以色列驻联合国特使发布了;X; 视频，他称哈马斯在 Shifa 医院旁边放映电影，建筑物的窗户似乎被照亮。

;

;世界卫生组织已记录了至少 93 起袭击事件自冲突开始以来，加沙地带的冲突造成 16 名值班医护人员死亡，并损坏或摧毁了 28 辆救护车。

;

;援助正在通过与埃及接壤的拉法过境点运送，该过境点是唯一开放的过境点，但冲突前的交付工作只有一小部分完成。自 10 月 21 日恢复有限运送以来，至少有 450 辆卡车运载食品、水和医疗用品进入加沙。

;

;数百名外国人和伤员被允许;上周离开加沙;前往埃及，但人道协调厅表示，自;

;加沙居民正面临严重的缺水问题。人道协调厅表示，两座海水淡化厂中的一座因缺乏燃料而关闭，另一座则以最低水平运行。来自以色列的三条输水管道中有两条正在运行。

;

;人道协调厅表示，由于缺乏电力和燃料，加沙唯一仍在运转的磨坊仍然无法研磨小麦，十一家面包店在冲突中受到打击。

;

;世界粮食计划署表示，加沙的大米和植物油等基本食品库存将在 1-3 天内耗尽。

;

;援助组织表示急需燃料;分发援助;并为医院供电，面包店和海水淡化厂。但以色列仍然禁止燃料入境，以色列称这些燃料可能被转给哈马斯用于军事目的。联合国援助负责人表示;“取得了一些进展”< /a>; 已就允许燃料进入加沙进行了谈判，但尚未确认发货。

;

;美国总统乔·拜登周一将宣布最新一批联邦资金，用于对美国最繁忙的铁路走廊的关键部分进行现代化改造从波士顿延伸到华盛顿特区。

;

;拜登强调 2021 年两党;针对美国铁路公司东北走廊 25 个客运铁路项目的基础设施法;，该项目为该地区每天约 80 万次出行提供服务，该地区占全国国内生产总值的 20%。

;<这笔资金将用于重建已有 100 多年历史的隧道和桥梁，并升级轨道、电力系统、信号、车站和其他基础设施。它还将帮助资助一项关于如何提高纽约和华盛顿之间的速度和效率的研究。

;

;“最重要的是，对于每年乘坐这条铁路走廊的超过 2 亿乘客来说，这些改进是美国交通部长皮特·布蒂吉格 (Pete Buttigieg) 在一份声明中表示：“我们将缩短出行时间并提高可靠性。”

;

;获得资金的主要项目为 38 亿美元，以帮助修复和扩建纽约和纽约之间交通繁忙的哈得逊河隧道。新泽西州，拨款 47 亿美元用于;弗雷德里克·道格拉斯隧道;以提供帮助缓解该线路最棘手的瓶颈之一，并耗资 21 亿美元更换一座横跨马里兰州萨斯奎哈纳河的铁路桥，以实现更高的速度。

;

;周一的活动在 ;至少第三次;拜登举行了一次活动，强调为东北走廊线提供资金，强调总统与走廊的个人联系。

;

;作为美国参议员，拜登乘坐美国铁路公司 (Amtrak) 行驶了超过 100 万英里，大部分时间往返于威尔明顿和华盛顿之间。美国铁路公司的威尔明顿车站以拜登的名字命名。

;

;“总统是一名火车专家。他坚信要改善美国的客运铁路，而且他比其他人更了解东北走廊，”白宫基础设施沙皇米奇·兰德里乌(Mitch Landrieu)说。

;美国财政部长珍妮特·耶伦本周将在旧金山会见中国国务院副总理何立峰，试图深化刚刚起步的合作在美国主办的环太平洋地区领导人峰会之前，世界最大的两个经济体之间进行经济对话。

;

;财政部表示，11 月 9 日至 10 日的会议还将召开由 10 月份发起的新经济和金融论坛。财政部、中国财政部和央行。

;

;耶伦于 7 月份首次会见了中国新任经济沙皇贺建奎，当时她;访问北京;，试图在美国对敏感技术限制日益严格的情况下稳定不断恶化的美中关系。

;<旧金山会议将在拜登政府于 11 月 11 日至 17 日接待亚太经济合作组织国家部长和领导人之前举行，美国总统乔·拜登计划在这次聚会上会见中国国家主席习近平。

;

;一位美国财政部高级官员淡化了耶伦与贺会议将产生具体“成果”的想法，称这不是“我们以一物换另一物”的“政策贸易”情况。

;

;但该官员表示，耶伦的一个关键目标是更好地了解新的美中经济沟通渠道将如何运作，以及如何确保“它不易受到冲击”，并补充道将会有更频繁的互动。

;

;耶伦还热衷于讨论中国官员正在考虑采取哪些措施来支持其疲软的经济增长，以及什么情况可能会改变他们的政策路径。

;

;这位官员表示，由于人们越来越担心中国将试图向美国和全球市场倾销更多制成品，预计耶伦将警告贺建奎不要对国有企业使用大规模工业补贴，并将美国企业拒之门外。

;< “本周，我将与我的同行谈谈我们对北京不公平经济行为的严重关切，包括其大规模使用非市场工具、市场准入壁垒以及对在华美国企业的强制行动， ” 耶伦在;意见文章; 由《华盛顿邮报》发表。

;

;她重申，美国正在寻求与中国的“良性竞争”，而不是试图通过供应链多元化行动来“引发”私营部门无序大规模撤出中国。并保护美国国家安全。”

;

;迄今为止的沟通已帮助美国官员向北京同行解释出口管制和限制美国对华投资等政策。

;

;但是耶伦表示，她与贺建奎的接触并不是要重建奥巴马时代广泛的美中战略与经济对话，该对话因其无效而受到广泛批评。

;

;相反，耶伦表示她“专注于具体的问题” ，我们可以在这些问题上取得切实进展的高度优先的经济议题。”

;

;其中包括合作应对全球挑战，例如应对气候变化、加快减免穷国债务以及减少支持恐怖主义的非法资金流动和非法毒品交易。

;弗拉基米尔·普京 (Vladimir Putin) 决定参选六名消息人士告诉路透社，此举将使他继续掌权到至少 2030 年，因为克里姆林宫领导人认为他必须带领俄罗斯度过数十年来最危险的时期。

;

;

;

;

;对于普京来说，民意调查显示他的;支持率;为 80 % 在俄罗斯境内，如果他参选，选举就是一个形式：在国家、官方媒体的支持下，在几乎没有主流公众异议的情况下，他肯定会获胜。

;

;

;另一位也了解克里姆林宫想法的消息人士证实，已经做出了决定，普京的顾问正在准备为了普京的参与。另外三位消息人士称，决定已经做出：普京将参选。

;

;其中一位消息人士表示，“我们看到的世界非常危险”。

;

;

;虽然许多外国外交官、间谍和官员表示，他们预计普京将终身掌权，但到目前为止尚未具体确认他参加 2024 年 3 月总统选举的计划。

;西方将普京视为战犯和独裁者导致俄罗斯陷入帝国式的土地掠夺，削弱了俄罗斯并建立了乌克兰国家地位，同时团结了西方并赋予了北约使命。

;

;

;“俄罗斯面临着西方的联合力量，因此不会发生重大变化。一位消息人士称，这是权宜之计。

;

;<被监禁的俄罗斯反对派政治家阿列克谢·纳瓦尔尼表示，普京已将俄罗斯带入了走向毁灭的战略死胡同，建立了一个脆弱的体系;腐败的阿谀奉承者;最终会带来混乱而不是稳定。

;

;“俄罗斯正在倒退”，;俄罗斯最受尊敬的人权活动人士之一奥列格·奥尔洛夫 (Oleg Orlov) 7 月对路透社表示。 “我们离开了共产主义极权主义，但现在又回到了另一种极权主义。”

;

;据估计，在短短一年半的战争中，已有数十万俄罗斯和乌克兰士兵阵亡或受伤。比 1979-1989 年整个阿富汗战争中苏联官方的伤亡还要多。

;

;在他叛变之前，;普里戈任;严厉谴责普京的将军们的战争及其无能的执行，并警告说，除非精英们认真起来，否则俄罗斯可能面临革命。< /p>;

;

;由富裕民主国家组成的七国集团 (G7) 集团可能会削弱其作为应对重大地缘政治危机的力量的相关性。其成员国之间显然在努力就以色列加沙战争采取坚定、统一的方法达成一致。

;

;来自英国、加拿大、法国、德国、意大利、日本、欧盟和美国的外交部长meet in Tokyo this week to discuss the conflict, which several global powers have warned could spiral and engulf the Middle East.

;

;If ministers do issue a communique after the meeting, it will likely address the conflict in general terms , reflecting the different concerns, and the divergent political and economic loyalties within the group, analysts say.

;

;"Europeans are divided and this division is also certainly visible within the G7," said Thomas Gomart, director of the French Institute of International Relations.

;

;Complicating matters is that the current chair of the group Japan has taken a cautious approach to the crisis, resisting pressure to fall in line with the pro-Israel stance of its closest ally, the United States, officials and analysts say.

;

;Officials from France and Canada, speaking on condition of anonymity, also said the strong US support for Israel, and concerns about a backlash from either Arab or Jewish segments of the populations of the G7 nations, have made reaching common positions challenging.

;

;From the beginning of the conflict, Japan has sought a "balanced" response, in part due to its diverse diplomatic interests in the region and its < a href="/world/israel-palestinian-conflict-tests-japans-oil-diplomacy-2023-10-17/">;dependency on the Middle East for oil;.

;

;Israeli diplomats , however, have intensively lobbied Japan in phone calls, emails and visits to Japanese officials, according to two sources familiar with the matter.

;

;The mounting casualties in Gaza have reinforced Japan's cautious approach, analysts say. Health officials in the Palestinian enclave say almost 10,000 Palestinians, mostly women and children, have been killed since Israel's bombardment began in retaliation for Oct. 7 attacks by the militant group Hamas.

;

;"I don't think ever in the past history of the G7 presidency under Japan it has come to this kind of a critical challenge," said Koichiro Tanaka, a professor at Tokyo's Keio University who specialises on international relations in the Middle East.

;

;A spokesperson for Japan's foreign ministry said it was expected that countries have different positions, but denied that G7 members were struggling to find common ground.

;

;The spokesperson declined to confirm whether a communique would be issued. A statement issued by G7 trade ministers from a meeting in Osaka late last month did not mention the war.

;

;The G7 was initially set up half a century ago to discuss global economic problems, but its scope has since broadened to represent the collective voice of major industrialised countries' on political and security issues.

;

;While the group in recent years has shown unity in sanctioning Russia over its Ukraine war and calling out so-called 'economic coercion' from China, they have not moved in lock step over the Israel-Gaza war.

;

;Since the war erupted, the G7 has issued just one joint statement on the conflict amounting to a few sentences. Other group members have issued joint statements.

;

;G7 divisions have also been evident at the United Nations, with France voting in favour of a resolution calling for a humanitarian truce in the conflict on Oct 26, the US opposing it and the group's other members abstaining.

;

;Agreeing specific wording on Israel's right to defend itself, the civilian casualties in Gaza and calls for a temporary halt in fighting will be difficult, officials say.

;

;Aside from rhetoric, Hideaki Shinoda, a professor at Tokyo University of Foreign Studies, said the G7 needed concrete proposals on how to get humanitarian aid into Gaza, where fuel, food, water and medical supplies are scarce, but that is also likely to prove a tall task.

;

;Israel has vowed to annihilate Hamas after the Iran-backed group attacked southern Israel, killing 1,400 people and taking more than 240 hostages. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has rejected global calls for a humanitarian ceasefire, saying any lull would play into the hands of Hamas, while the United States has proposed temporary, localised pauses in the fighting.

;

;One G7 official said members were deliberately trying to hide their differences so as not to "play into Russia's hands".

;

;China and Russia are using the conflict as an opportunity to burnish their credentials as the ;champions of the developing world;, as well as to oppose the United States.

;

;Any sign of disunity or failure to stem the conflict may only embolden these G7 detractors, analysts say.

;

;"It's also a question of how China and Russia will interpret these developments and how they will try testing us," said Kunihiko Miyake, research director at The Canon Institute for Global Studies, a Tokyo-based think tank.

;Russian drone attacks on Odesa late on Sunday evening left at least five people injured, set trucks with grain on fire and damaged one of the city's principal art galleries, Ukrainian officials in the Black Sea port said.

;

;"On November 6, the Odesa National Art Museum turns 124 years old," Oleh Kiper, governor of the Odesa region, of which the Odesa city is the administrative centre, said on the Telegram messaging app. "On the eve of November 6, the Russians 'congratulated' our architectural monument with a missile that hit nearby."

;

;The walls of the building were damaged, some windows and glass were broken, he said.

;

;Kipper later said that 15 Russia-launched drones were destroyed over the city. Several high-rise residential buildings were damaged and warehouse and trucks with grain caught fire, which was promptly extinguished.

;

;It was not clear whether the buildings and the trucks were hit by the drones or falling debris. There was no immediate comment from Russia.

;

;The Odesa National Art Museum, in one of the oldest palaces of Odesa, housed more than 10,000 pieces of art before the war, including paintings by some of the best-known Russian and Ukrainian artists of the late 19th and early 20th century.

;

;The Odesa city council published a video showing blown out windows and debris inside what it said was the art museum.

;

;On the street near the museum, the attack left a several-meter deep hole. According to the city authorities, one person was injured there.

;

;Kiper said that all five of the injured, from around the city, were hospitalised.

;But while some consensus was reached on the need to regulate AI, disagreements remain over exactly how that should happen – and who will lead such efforts.

;

;Risks around rapidly-developing AI have been an increasingly high priority for policymakers since Microsoft-backed Open AI ;(MSFT.O); released ChatGPT to the public last year.

;

;The chatbot's unprecedented ability to respond to prompts with human-like fluency has led some experts to call for a pause in the development of such systems, warning they could gain autonomy and threaten humanity.

;

;Sunak talked of being "privileged and excited" to host Tesla-founder ;(TSLA.O); Musk, but European lawmakers warned of too much technology and data being held by a small number of companies in one country, the United States.

;

;"Having just one single country with all of the technologies, all of the private companies, all the devices, all the skills, will be a failure for all of us," French Minister of the Economy and Finance Bruno Le Maire told reporters.

;

;The UK has also diverged from the EU by proposing light-touch approach to AI regulation, in contrast to Europe's ;AI Act;, which is close to being finalised and will bind developers of what are deemed "high risk" applications to stricter controls.

;

;"I came here to sell our AI Act," Vera Jourova, Vice President of the European Commission.

;

;Jourova said, while she did not expect other countries to copy the bloc's laws wholesale, some agreement on global rules was required.

;

;"If the democratic world will not be rule-makers, and we become rule-takers, the battle will be lost," she said.

;

;While projecting an image of unity, attendees said

;

;the three main power blocs in attendance – the US, the EU,

;

;and China – tried to assert their dominance.

;

;Some suggested Harris had upstaged Sunak when the US government announced its own ;AI safety institute; – just as Britain had a week earlier – and she delivered a speech in London highlighting the technology's short-term risks, in contrast to the summit's focus on existential threats.

;

;"It was fascinating that just as we announced our AI safety institute, the Americans announced theirs," said attendee Nigel Toon, CEO of British AI firm Graphcore.

;

;China's presence at the summit and its decision to sign off on the "Bletchley Declaration" was trumpeted as a success by British officials.

;

;China's vice minister of science and technology said the country was willing to work with all sides on AI governance.

;

;Signalling tension between China and the West, however, Wu Zhaohui told delegates: "Countries regardless of their size and scale have equal rights to develop and use AI."

;

;The Chinese minister participated in the ministerial roundtable on the Thursday, his ministry said. He did not participate in the public events on the second day, however.

;

;A recurring theme of the behind-closed-door discussions, highlighted by a number of attendees, was the potential risks of open-source AI, which gives members of the public free access to experiment with the code behind the technology.

;

;Some experts have warned that open-source models could be used by terrorists to create chemical weapons, or even create a super-intelligence beyond human control.

;

;Speaking with Sunak at a live event in London on Thursday, Musk said: "It will get to the point where you've got open-source AI that will start to approach human-level intelligence, or perhaps exceed it. I don't know quite what to do about it."

;

;Yoshua Bengio, an AI pioneer appointed to lead a "state of the science" report commissioned as part of the Bletchley Declaration, told Reuters the risks of open-source AI were a high priority.

;

;He said: "It could be put in the hands of bad actors, and it could be modified for malicious purposes. You can't have the open-source release of these powerful systems, and still protect the public with the right guardrails."
